Sulfur-doped activated carbon supported platinum species as robust catalysts for nitrobenzene hydrogenation to p-Aminophenol Jie Luo Investigation Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft Chaojie Zhang Methodology Validation Investigation Chong Yao Methodology Investigation Dandan Ma Formal analysis Yixin Chen Formal analysis Min Tian Formal analysis Haoxuan Xie Formal analysis Limei Pan Validation Yaoyao Zhen Methodology Ruihao Chen Methodology Jiwei Wu Writing – original draft Chunshan Lu Formal analysis Feng Feng Formal analysis Xiaoliang Xu Formal analysis Qingtao Wang Formal analysis Methodology Investigation ⁎ Qunfeng Zhang Supervision Methodology Funding acquisition Investigation Writing – original draft Xiaonian Li Supervision Methodology Funding acquisition Investigation State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310041, China State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology College of Chemical Engineering Zhejiang University of Technology Hangzhou 310041 China State Key Laboratory Breeding Base of Green Chemistry Synthesis Technology, College of Chemical Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology, Hangzhou 310041, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Nitrobenzene catalytic hydrogenation is the main synthesis method for the preparation of p-Aminophenol, but it is a great challenge to manufacture a catalyst with excellent catalytic performance. In this study, the authors explored the impact of S-doping on the catalytic performance of the platinum-based catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of nitrobenzene for p-Aminophenol production. To this end, the activated carbon carrier was modified through high-temperature calcination with an impregnation technique that incorporates organic sulfur. The study further evaluated the effects of the amount of sulfur doping on the particle size of the catalyst as well as its performance. It was theorized that the strong interaction between S and platinum (Pt) resulted in the capture of some of the Pt electrons by the sulfur-doped activated carbon carrier, reducing the reactivity of the catalyst and suppressing the over-hydrogenation side reaction. As a result, the catalyst demonstrated improved selectivity towards the formation of p-Aminophenol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nitrobenzene hydrogenation p-Aminophenol Sulfur doping Electron transfer Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction p-Aminophenol is a widely utilized organic chemical intermediate in various industries, including rubber, dyestuff, and pharmaceuticals [1–4]. Despite its extensive industrial applications, traditional methods for its production, such as aniline coupled reduction and phenol nitrosation, are often accompanied by adverse consequences such as increased waste generation, elevated energy consumption, and environmental pollution, which are incompatible with modern sustainable chemical development standards [5–9]. Consequently, hydrogenation and rearrangement of nitrobenzene has become a prevalent industrial method for the production of p-Aminophenol, with catalysts commonly composed of precious metals such as Pt, Pd, Rt, Au, and Ru. While these precious metal catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity and are easily separable, they present challenges such as resource depletion, elevated costs, and residual heavy metal contamination [10–13]. The use of noble metal catalysts in nitrobenzene hydrogenation reactions poses not only the challenge of high cost, but also that of excessive reactivity, leading to low selectivity of the final product and hindering industrialization [14,15]. To address these issues, various studies have been conducted to improve the cost-effectiveness, selectivity, and stability of catalytic hydrogenation reactions. One approach involves the use of non-precious metal Ni as the core catalyst with increased loading and modification, which leads to equal activity as compared to precious metal catalysts while reducing production cost [16]. Another approach involves the combination of carbon nitride (CN) with Ni to achieve high catalytic activity and selectivity, and to prevent Ni corrosion through electron transportation facilitated by the special structure of CN [17]. The heteroatomic treatment of the carrier and the addition of transition metals to regulate the morphology and size of metal nanoparticles can also be used to control the exposure of active metal sites and improve catalytic performance. For catalyst carriers, activated carbon and silica are commonly used, while mesoporous activated carbon or carbon nanotubes with larger pore sizes and titanium dioxide are also employed in nitrobenzene hydrogenation reactions [18,19]. In recent years, the study of metal catalysts with sulfur-doped carbon carriers has gained significant attention and has demonstrated its effectiveness in a range of applications, making it a crucial component in various chemical reactions in the fields of energy, environment, and materials. In the energy sector, sulfur-doped metal catalysts are employed as catalysts for fuel cells, facilitating the conversion of chemical energy stored in fuel into electrical energy [20,21]. One example is the use of sulfur-doped platinum catalysts as anode catalysts in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC) [22]. In the environmental field, these catalysts play a role in purifying air pollutants such as nitrogen oxides (NOx) and sulfur dioxide (SO2) produced by automobiles and power plants [23]. For instance, in selective catalytic reduction (SCR) systems, sulfur-doped titanium dioxide catalysts are utilized for the decomposition of NOx into nitrogen and oxygen [24]. In the field of materials, sulfur-doped metal catalysts are utilized in the synthesis of advanced materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and metal-organic frameworks. For instance, sulfur-doped iron catalysts are utilized in chemical vapor deposition (CVD) synthesis of graphene. To summarize, sulfur-doped metal catalysts play a critical role in promoting chemical reactions, enhancing energy conversion and storage efficiency, purifying air pollutants, and synthesizing advanced materials [25]. The addition of metal atoms to the surface of sulfur-doped carbon in the formation of a hybrid catalyst results in improved catalytic selectivity and stability compared to metal catalysts alone. This is due to the contribution of metal atoms to the number of active sites for reaction, the exploitation of strong interactions between the heteroatoms on the carrier and the metal ions to direct electrons to participate in the reaction, and the adjustment of catalytic activity and electronic properties of the loaded metal catalyst through the incorporation of sulfur as an element. The strong interaction between the sulfur-containing carrier and the metal facilitates the anchoring of the metal and regulation of its electronic structure, which effectively enhances catalyst stability, product selectivity, and controls the size and distribution of metal on the catalyst surface [26–29]. Herein, we report a simple loaded sulfur-doped carbon carrier Pt catalyst applied to the preparation of p-Aminophenol by hydrogenative rearrangement of nitrobenzene, where the sulfur-containing precursor phenyl sulfide was doped onto the activated carbon carrier by high-temperature calcination, and then the metal Pt was loaded onto the surface of the activated carbon using impregnation, and the abundant sulfur-containing sites on the carrier were able to make the Pt metal particle size gradually decrease, with a certain degree of adjustment of the metal [30]. We also found that the sulfur-containing compounds acted as a toxicizing agent that could effectively inhibit the hydrogenation activity of the metal in the hydrogenation reaction, thus preventing the excessive hydrogenation of the intermediate phenylhydroxylamine generated during the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to produce the by-product aniline. The electron transfer between the metal Pt and the S-doped carbon carrier is enhanced with the increase of sulfur addition, and electrons move from Pt to the surface of the sulfur-doped carbon carrier, increasing the proportion of the higher valence Pt, reducing the reaction activity while improving the selectivity of p-Aminophenol. We examined the catalysts by TEM, XPS, XRD and other characterization means and further explored the possible reaction mechanism. 2 Experiments and methods 2.1 Chemicals and materials Chemicals and reagents: Chlorplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O, Pt≥37.5%, Shanxi Rock New Materials Co, Ltd.), activated carbon (powder, Macklin), nitrobenzene (C6H5NO2, 99%, Macklin), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 95%−98%, Sinopharm), Dodecyltrimethylammonium Bromide (CTAB, 97%, Macklin), p-Aminophenol (C6H7NO, ≥98%, HPLC, Macklin), aniline (C6H7N, ≥99.9%, GC, Sinopharm), 4,4′-diaminodiphenyl ether (C12H12N2O, 98%, Macklin), o-Aminophenol (C6H7NO, 98%, Sinopharm), diphenyl sulfide (C12H10S, ≥98.0%, Macklin) , Sodium borohydride(NaBH4, ≥98.0%, Macklin). 2.2 Catalysts preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of sulfur-doped activated carbon carrier The sulfur doping amount was measured as 3 wt%, 5 wt%, 10 wt%, and 0.471 mL, 0.784 mL, and 1.567 mL of benzene sulfide respectively, and the benzene sulfide was mixed with 3 g of activated carbon and anhydrous ethanol in a 50 mL beaker, stirred at 300 r/min for 8 h at room temperature with magnetic stirring, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 120 °C for 8 h. The dried sulfur-containing activated carbon was then placed in a tube furnace under N2 atmosphere at a temperature rise rate of 3 °C/min to 450 °C for 3 h, and the nitrogen gas was passed at a rate of 100 mL/min. The sulfur-doped activated carbon carriers were collected after the temperature of the tube furnace dropped to room temperature, and the sulfur-doped amount of 3 wt% was recorded as CS1, the sulfur-doped amount of 5 wt% was recorded as CS2, and the sulfur-doped amount of 10 wt% was recorded as CS3. 2.2.2 Preparation of sulfur-doped catalysts 5 g of chloroplatinic acid powder was dissolved in deionized water and diluted to 50 mL to obtain a chloroplatinic acid solution with a concentration of 0.1 g/mL, and the precious metal platinum was loaded by the wet impregnation method with a loading of about 2 wt% of platinum. Separately, 2.5 g of sulfur-doped activated carbon carrier CS1–3 was weighed and mixed with 15 mL of deionized water in a 250 mL three-neck flask. The magnetic stirring rate was maintained at 300 r/min, and the water bath was warmed up to 60 °C, and then the prepared chloroplatinic acid solution (0.1 g/mL) was added drop by drop according to the desired loading, and then the configured NaOH solution (0.1 g/mL) was added drop by drop after stirring at this temperature for about 120 min, and the pH of the mixture was adjusted to 8∼9, and then the appropriate amount of sodium borohydride powder was added after stirring for about 60 min. The stirring was continued for about 60 min and then an appropriate amount of sodium borohydride powder was added for reduction, and the stirring was stopped after 40 min of reduction. The mixture in the three-mouth flask was filtered and washed repeatedly with deionized water. The washed catalyst was spread on a surface dish and subsequently dried in a vacuum drying oven at 110 °C for 12 h to obtain the sulfur-doped activated carbon loaded Pt catalyst Pt/CS1–3. (Pt/AC was prepared in the same way and used as a control group for the undoped treatment). 2.3 Catalyst characterization An X-ray diffractometer of X'Pert PRO type from PNAlytical, The Netherlands, was used for the characterization. Test conditions: the light tube target was a Cu target, Cu Kα radiation (0.1541 nm) was used, the operating current was 40 mA, the operating voltage was 40 kV, the scan rate was 5 °C-min−1, and the scan range was 10–80°. The average particle size of Pt nanoparticles was calculated using the Scherrer-Warren formula. The elemental composition of the catalyst surface and the chemical state of the elements were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and the XPS characterization was performed on a Kratos AXOS Ultra DLD with an Al Kα-ray excitation source (hν = 1486.6 eV) and an operating current of 3 mA, The binding energy of the catalyst peaks was corrected using the C 1 s peak (B.E. = 284.8 eV). XRF was performed using an X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (ARL ADVANT'X IntelliPowerTM 4200) from ThermoFisher, USA. The range of elements analyzed was Be(4)-U(92), and the concentration measurement range was ppm∼100%. The X-ray tube was a Rh target, anode 4GN end window tube, ultra-thin beryllium window (75 um) and UniQuant semi-quantitative analysis software was used to analyze samples in the range of powder, solid and liquid, and the accuracy of the results was close to the quantitative level. TEM observation of catalyst morphology was performed using a transmission electron microscope (Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin) from FEI, The Netherlands, operating at 300 kV. The catalyst was ground into a powder and a small amount of sample was sonicated using anhydrous ethanol as dispersant. A small amount of the ethanol solution containing the catalyst is dabbed onto the copper sheet with a capillary tube and used for electron microscopy analysis after the ethanol has evaporated. The shape, size and lattice stripes of the metal can be observed at a magnification of up to 5 nm (up to 2 nm, but not as good as 5 nm due to overfocusing), and the color difference is used to determine whether the metal particles on the catalyst are uniformly dispersed. The specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size of the catalysts were determined by using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 fully automated specific surface and porosity analyzer with argon adsorption at low temperature. The catalyst samples were processed at 100 °C for 3 h to remove the impurities adsorbed on the surface of the samples, and the mass of the catalyst samples was between 0.1 and 0.2 g. The catalyst samples were physically adsorbed in liquid argon for 12 h before they were desorbed in liquid argon, and the adsorption and desorption curves were plotted using the adsorption amounts of gasses at different pressures to analyze the specific surface area, average pore size and pore volume of the catalyst samples. (The pore size distribution was measured from the desorption data in the adsorption isotherm by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method). Raman spectroscopy (Raman) was used to determine the degree of defects on the surface of carbon materials, and the instrument was a LabRAM HR800 model Raman spectrometer manufactured by Horiba on a He-Ne laser with an excitation wavelength of 633 nm and a CCD detector with a sweep range of 100∼2200 cm−1. H2-TPR was performed on a VDSorb-91i-MS chemisorption analyzer, model VDSorb, manufactured by Ward Instruments, using H2 as the probe molecule and a detector. Typically, a 50 mg sample was first pretreated in 100 °C Ar for 1 h to remove water from the sample, after cooling down to 30 °C in an Ar atmosphere, the sample was ramped up from 30 °C to 650 °C in an 10 vol% H2/Ar atmosphere in a 5 °C/min program. Infrared spectroscopic analysis of the catalyst was performed on the VERTEX 70 V infrared spectrometer manufactured by Brook. First, the infrared spectrum of Pt/AC catalyst was collected in Ar atmosphere and the background was deducted. Then the infrared spectrum of Pt/CS was detected. Temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) was performed on a VDSorb-91i-MS chemisorption analyzer, model VDSorb, manufactured by Ward Instruments, using H2 as the probe molecule. Typically, a 50 mg sample was first pretreated in 100 °C Ar for 1 h to remove water from the sample, held at 75 °C for 1 h in a 10 vol% H2/Ar atmosphere, and after cooling down to 30 °C in an Ar atmosphere, the sample was ramped up from 30 °C to 700 °C in an Ar atmosphere in a 5 °C/min program, and hydrogen desorption was detected with a TPD detector. The ICP-OES/MS analysis was performed using Agilent's Agilent 7800 instrument. We first carried out microwave digestion on the catalyst, and after the digestion solution was fixed to a certain volume, the final test was carried out on the sample. 2.4 Hydrogenation tests Pursuant to the specified reaction conditions, the necessary quantities of reactants and catalyst were meticulously measured and combined. Specifically, 21 mL of nitrobenzene, 14 mL of concentrated sulfuric acid, and 0.2 g of either Pt/AC or Pt/CS1–3 catalyst were blended with 126 mL of deionized water and then transferred to a high-pressure mechanical stirred kettle with a capacity of 0.5 liters. Additionally, 0.1 g of dodecyltrimethylammonium bromide surfactant was incorporated into the reaction mixture. The stirring rate was set to 1000 rotations per minute, the reaction temperature was maintained at 70 °C, and the hydrogen pressure was maintained at 1.0 megapascals. Prior to initiation of the reaction, the air inside the kettle was repeatedly replaced with nitrogen, and the gas tightness of the kettle was confirmed. During the reaction, hydrogen was added as required and the gas consumption was continuously monitored. Upon completion of the reaction, the temperature of the reaction kettle was cooled to room temperature, the pressure was released, the catalyst was recovered via filtration, and the filtrate was then diluted with ethanol. The products of the nitrobenzene reduction reaction were quantified using Agilent liquid chromatography, with a 4.6 mm by 150 mm C18 reversed column. The single sample injection time was set to 30 min. The mobile phases used were ammonium acetate (mobile phase A), acetonitrile (mobile phase B), and isopropanol (mobile phase C), with a gradient elution applied to achieve a decrease in the proportion of ammonium acetate from 85% to 10% and a concurrent decrease in the proportion of acetonitrile from 85% to 10% within 30 min. Furthermore, the proportion of ammonium acetate was decreased from 85% to 10%, the proportion of acetonitrile was increased from 10% to 85%, and the proportion of isopropanol was maintained at 5% within the same 30 min timeframe. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The quantitative analysis of the sulfur content and other elemental composition of the catalysts Pt/AC (prior to sulfur doping) and Pt/CS1–3 (with varying levels of sulfur doping) was performed using X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF). The evaluation outcomes are presented in Table 1 . As compared to the Pt/AC catalyst, the sulfur content in the Pt/CS1 was elevated to 1.67 weight percent (wt%) due to the incremental increase in the addition of phenyl sulfide during the synthesis procedure. The sulfur content in Pt/CS2 and Pt/CS3 was further increased to 2.73 wt% and 4.65 wt%, respectively. This indicates the effective incorporation of sulfur into the activated carbon support after being subjected to high-temperature calcination. The loading of the metal platinum (Pt) in all catalysts was observed to be within the range of 2.13–2.61%, which was consistent with the expected loading, demonstrating the successful surface anchoring of the metal Pt on the sulfur-doped support. The physical properties of the catalysts Pt/AC and Pt/CS1–3 were characterized using Argon Physical Adsorption-Desorption. The impact of sulfur doping and high temperature roasting on the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the catalysts was evaluated and compared. As depicted in Fig. 1 (a), the Argon adsorption-desorption curve of the Pt/AC catalyst displays a Type IV isothermal adsorption pattern, exhibiting a rapid rise in helium adsorption at low relative pressures, which reflects its microporous structure. Additionally, a hysteresis loop structure, indicative of the presence of both mesopores and micropores, is observed in the second half of the curve. Similarly, the Argon adsorption-desorption curves of the Pt/CS1–3 catalysts, as shown in Fig. 1(b–d), demonstrate a Type IV isothermal adsorption pattern, preserving the original microporous and mesoporous structures of the catalysts. The pore structure parameters of the catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . The specific surface area and pore volume of the Pt/AC catalyst were determined to be 1295 m2/g and 0.84 cm3/g, respectively, exhibiting minimal fluctuations compared to the Pt/CS1–3 catalysts. The average pore size was observed to be around 2.8 nm, indicating that sulfur doping and high temperature roasting had limited influence on the pore structure of the catalyst support. The structural properties of the catalysts Pt/AC and Pt/CS1–3 were further analyzed using Raman spectroscopy. Two significant peaks near 1355 cm−1 and 1590 cm−1 were identified as the D-band (D) and G-band (G), respectively. Fig. 2 displays the Raman spectra of the catalysts, with two prominent peaks being observed, the D-band at approximately 1358 cm−1 and the G-band at approximately 1579 cm−1. According to previous research studies [31,32], the D-band is primarily a result of the SP3 hybridization of carbon and the presence of defect sites, while the G-band is produced by the stretching of atoms in SP2 bonds, including the carbon-carbon and carbon-sulfur bonds. The ratio between the height or area of the two peaks, commonly referred to as the ID/IG value, reflects the extent of defects on the sample surface. Higher values of ID/IG indicate a higher number of defect sites and greater degrees of disorder and doping. The ID/IG values of the catalyst Pt/AC, Pt/CS1, Pt/CS2, and Pt/CS3 were determined to be 1.41, 1.44, 1.42, and 1.45. Although there is little difference between the positions of D and G peaks of the catalyst, we believe that the sulfur doping content is not enough to greatly affect the defects and the degree of graphitization of the carbon carrier. The structural characteristics of the catalysts Pt/AC and Pt/CS1–3 were analyzed via X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRD) to determine the impact of sulfur doping on the size of Pt metal nanoparticles. The standard XRD patterns were compared to literature data [33], and it was established that the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 40°, 46° and 68° correspond to the (111), (200) and (220) crystallographic planes of Pt, respectively, while the diffraction peak at 2θ = 24° corresponds to the (002) crystallographic plane of carbon and the diffraction peak at 2θ = 43° corresponds to the (100) crystallographic plane of carbon. The XRD pattern of catalyst Pt/AC exhibited a diffraction peak only at 2θ = 40°, demonstrating that the Pt nanoparticles were well-dispersed on the activated carbon carrier and had a small particle size. As shown in Fig. 3 , the Pt diffraction peaks at 2θ = 46° and 68° were not observed on the curves of catalysts Pt/CS1, Pt/CS2, and Pt/CS3, indicating that the Pt nanoparticles were also evenly dispersed on the sulfur-containing activated carbon carriers. The half-height width of the diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern is a direct indicator of the average size of the metal nanoparticles, where a narrower half-height width implies smaller particle size and vice versa. The results showed that, with increasing sulfur doping, the diffraction peak of the Pt (111) crystal plane decreased, implying a decrease in the size of Pt nanoparticles. However, the magnitude of the decrease in particle size was not the same for all catalysts Pt/CS1–3. This outcome can be attributed to the strong interaction between Pt and S, which prevented the agglomeration of Pt nanoparticles on the sulfur-containing catalysts. The hypothesis of HSAB [34] posits that Pt and S have a strong covalent affinity, resulting in Pt nanoparticles being likely to nucleate in proximity to C atoms adjacent to S defect sites on the carbon carriers. This contributes to the stability of the Pt nanoparticles and prevents migration, thus avoiding the aggregation of small particles into larger ones. This conclusion aligns with the findings of Shen et al. [35], who demonstrated that the strong Pt-S interaction could prevent the formation of Pt-Pt bonds and selectively introduce Pt into sites with abundant sulfur atoms to enhance dispersion. In the present experiment, the reduction in particle size primarily arises from the inhibition of further "growth" of Pt nanoparticles, and a certain amount of S doping is required to prevent the aggregation and growth of Pt nanoparticles. However, further increases in the amount of sulfur doping beyond this threshold may not result in a continued reduction in particle size. The impact of sulfur doping on the morphology of Pt nanoparticles loaded onto activated carbon carriers was assessed through transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis. As shown in Fig. 4 , high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) revealed the lattice spacing of Pt to be 0.227 nm, consistent with the (111) crystal plane of Pt. The uniform dispersion of Pt nanoparticles on the activated carbon carriers in catalysts Pt/AC (Fig. 5 (a)) and Pt/C1–3 (Fig. 5 (b-d)) was observed through TEM analysis, while partial agglomeration was observed in Pt NPs on Pt/AC catalysts. The average particle size of Pt metal nanoparticles was calculated to be approximately 3.73 nm in Pt/AC, 3.12 nm in Pt/CS1, 2.13 nm in Pt/CS2, and 2.09 nm in Pt/CS3, respectively. The results of TEM analysis indicated that the reduction in particle size corresponded to the observations from XRD analysis, which indicated that the modification of the activated carbon carriers through sulfur doping had a positive effect on adjusting the metal dispersion. The strong Pt-S interaction prevented the particle size from growing, thus improving the dispersion of Pt nanoparticles. The utilization of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was employed to conduct a quantitative and qualitative analysis of the chemical states and the surface species composition of the Pt/AC and Pt/CS1–3 catalysts. The results of the characterization are depicted in Fig. 6 . The broad sweeps of Pt/AC and Pt/CS1–3 catalysts allow for the determination of their main compositional elements. The Pt 4f energy spectrum peak, located near a binding energy of 72 eV, the S 2p energy spectrum peak, near a binding energy of 164 eV, the C 1 s energy spectrum peak, near a binding energy of 284 eV, and the O 1 s energy spectrum peak, near a binding energy of 532 eV, can all be observed in the XPS spectra. The elemental composition of the catalysts Pt/AC and Pt/CS1–3 was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and the results are presented in Table 3 . The semi-quantitative surface elemental composition analysis reveals an increase in sulfur content in the catalyst Pt/CS1–3 with increasing sulfur doping levels, with values of 1.68 wt%, 2.06 wt%, and 3.56 wt%, respectively. This is in agreement with the findings of the X-ray fluorescence (XRF) characterization, which demonstrates that heteroatomic sulfur was successfully doped into the activated carbon carrier following high-temperature roasting. In order to examine the interaction and electronic effects between sulfur and platinum, the XPS narrow sweep qualitative analysis was performed on the S and Pt in the catalysts. The analysis was corrected for C 1 s and the corrected S 2p XPS spectra, ranging from 160 to 175 eV binding energy, were processed using peak splitting. The results of the processing, as shown in Fig. 7 , indicate that the catalysts Pt/CS1–3 (a-c) all contain three sulfur functional groups, including the straight sulfur chain functional group at 163.9 eV, the thiophene functional group at 165.1 eV, and the sulfate functional group at 168.2 eV [36–38]. The presence of the thioether functional group in the phenyl sulfide suggests that high-temperature roasting has led to Phenylene sulfide pyrolyzed at 450 °C Celsius, So we carried out infrared spectroscopic analysis on four catalysts, as shown in Fig. S4. Compared with Pt/AC, Pt/CS showed new vibration bands at 1182 cm−1 and 1454 cm−1, which were due to the effect of the carbon-sulfur bond. This implies that the sulfur atoms in the sulfur-doped carbon material are bonded to the carbon atoms not only through van der Waals forces, but also through chemical covalent bonds, thereby stabilizing them on the carbon carrier. This further demonstrates the successful doping of heteroatomic sulfur into the activated carbon carrier. The Pt 4f X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the catalysts Pt/AC (a) and Pt/CS1–3 (b-d) are depicted in Fig. 8 . As indicated by the relevant literature [8] and standard references, the binding energy sites of Pt0 and Pt2+ are situated around 71.4 eV and 72.7 eV, respectively, with the former exhibiting superior activity and the latter having a diminished electron cloud density. Moreover, at a binding energy of 74.4 eV lies Pt4+. According to literature [39], high-valence Pt in the hydrogenation reaction of nitrobenzene dominated by Pt-based catalysts tends to be inactive and it is the low-valence Pt that plays a key role. Table 4 illustrates the gradual decrease in the peak intensity of Pt0 in the catalysts Pt/AC and Pt/CS3 with the proportions of Pt/AC (68.1%), Pt/CS1 (61.1%), Pt/CS2 (59.9%), and Pt/CS3 (49.8%), respectively. On the other hand, the peak intensity of Pt2+ increased with the proportions of Pt/AC (23.4%), Pt/CS1 (28.3%), Pt/CS2 (21.1%), and Pt/CS3 (32.6%), respectively. Additionally, the peaks of Pt4+ also increased with the proportions of Pt/AC (8.5%), Pt/CS1 (18.6%), Pt/CS2 (19.6%), and Pt/CS3 (17.6%), respectively. This indicates the presence of a strong interaction between Pt and S [40]. The presence of S attracts the electrons in the outer layer of Pt, leading to a high-valence state of Pt. With the increase of sulfur content in the catalyst, there is a notable trend of increasing the high-valence state of Pt. As a result, Pt loses electrons, the electron cloud density decreases, and the content of Pt in the low-valence state decreases. In order to further demonstrate the interaction and electronic effects between sulfur and platinum, we performed H2-TPR characterization on the catalyst, as shown in Fig. S3. With the increase of sulfur doping amount, the hydrogen reduction peak temperature gradually increased, indicating the existence of electronic interaction between sulfur-doped carrier and Pt, which effectively suppressed the reduction of Pt. This further proves the electronic transfer phenomenon between Pt and sulfur. To verify the phenomenon of decreased catalytic activity of sulfur-doped carbon-supported catalyst for nitrobenzene hydrogenation, we used H2-TPD to study the adsorption and dissociation behavior of sulfur (S) on the catalyst surface, as well as the effect of sulfur on the adsorption of hydrogen (H2) on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. S3, the catalyst exhibited a chemical desorption peak of hydrogen in the range of 200–400 °C, and with the increase of sulfur doping content, the chemical desorption peak of H2 gradually shifted to lower temperatures, indicating that the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for H2 gradually decreased, leading to a reduction in catalytic activity. 3.2 Catalytic performance The performance evaluation of the Pt/CS1–3 and Pt/AC catalysts with varying sulfur concentrations is presented in Fig. 9 (a–c) and Table 5 . The Pt/AC catalyst was found to exhibit the shortest reaction time and complete nitrobenzene conversion, however, the selectivity towards aminophenol was recorded as 49.4%. Fig. 9 (b, c) shows that this catalyst was characterized by the fastest hydrogen consumption rate, with roughly equal hydrogen consumption, and a by-product selectivity of 32.1% for aniline and 4.4% for 4,4-diaminodiphenyl ether. The selectivity was improved for all catalysts treated with sulfur doping, with the selectivity of p-Aminophenol for Pt/CS1 reaching 60.3%, which represents an improvement of approximately 10%. As the sulfur content increased, the selectivity of p-Aminophenol for Pt/CS2 increased to 63.7%, and for Pt/CS3 to 65.1%. This improvement in selectivity was accompanied by an extension in reaction time and a significant reduction in the hydrogen consumption rate. The sulfur-containing catalyst reduced the selectivity of aniline and 4,4-diaminodiphenyl ether, the main by-products, which indicates that the sulfur-containing catalyst effectively inhibited the formation of aniline as a by-product. The formation of 4,4-diaminodiphenyl ether was observed to arise from the reaction between p-Aminophenol and phenylhydroxylamine or its own two-molecule dehydration. Overly high catalyst activity was found to lead to an untimely rearrangement of phenylhydroxylamine, while an extended reaction time would result in the formation of 4,4-diaminodiphenyl ether through two-molecule dehydration, with the probability of such dehydration increasing [41]. Based on the results of characterization and evaluation, the TOF values for the Pt/AC and Pt/CS1–3 catalysts were calculated. The calculation was performed using the formula TOF = n0C/tnPt, where n0 represents the initial molarity of nitrobenzene [42], C is the conversion of nitrobenzene, t is the reaction time, and nPt is the number of exposed platinum atoms. The value of nPt was determined using the equation nPt = mxDPt/MPt, where m is the catalyst mass, x is the mass fraction of platinum in the catalyst, DPt is the dispersion of platinum calculated using the circular sphere model, and MPt is the relative atomic mass of platinum. The results, presented in Table 5, demonstrate that the Pt/AC catalyst has the highest activity with a TOF value of 7452.7 h−1. Conversely, with increasing sulfur doping, the TOF values gradually decrease, with the TOF value of the Pt/CS3 catalyst reaching 1344.3 h−1. In order to eliminate the influence of particle size on the catalytic performance of the catalyst, we also characterized and evaluated the performance of Pt/AC catalyst with a particle size of 2.16 nm (Fig. S1 and Table S1). We found that with the decrease of particle size, the catalyst did not show an increased selectivity towards the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to produce amino phenol. This also eliminates the influence caused by the size effect. Traditionally, the presence of sulfur-containing substances has been shown to result in catalyst poisoning and decreased activity. This is because the strong adsorption of these substances onto the catalyst surface can cover the active metal sites, thus hindering effective substrate adsorption and leading to the loss of activity. In this study, however, the sulfur atoms were doped on the activated carbon carrier after high-temperature roasting, forming a structure of -C-S-C-. While a portion of the active metal sites was covered at the junction of the metal and the carrier, there were still a large number of metal nanoparticles with a surface free of sulfur, allowing for the catalytic hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to take place. While the activity of the catalysts for nitrobenzene hydrogenation was reduced, the appropriate amount of sulfur doping was still able to extend the reaction time without impacting the nitrobenzene conversion [43]. The size of the Pt metal nanoparticles plays a crucial role in determining their catalytic hydrogenation activity, as smaller particle size results in greater exposure of active sites. It is believed that the increase in sulfur doping contributes to the improved selectivity of p-Aminophenol due to the increased electron effect. The interaction between Pt and S results in electron transfer from Pt to the sulfur-doped activated carbon carrier, leading to a decrease in the density of the electron clouds on the Pt surface and an increase in the proportion of higher valence Pt, which reduces the reaction activity while enhancing the selectivity of p-Aminophenol. The stability of the catalyst was also evaluated, with the catalyst Pt/CS2 being selected for nitrobenzene selective hydrogenation experiments. The results, as presented in Fig. 10 , show that the selectivity of p-Aminophenol was largely maintained at 63.5% after 11 cycles, with a conversion of nitrobenzene sustained at 99%. These findings suggest that the catalyst Pt/CS2 exhibits good stability and the strong interaction between S and Pt remains intact during multiple sets of experiments. The results of the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) characterization of the Pt/CS2 catalyst after 11 applications and prior to application are presented in Fig. 11 (a). A comparison of the XRD patterns before and after 11 applications reveals the absence of diffraction peaks at 2θ = 46° and 68° on the (200) and (220) crystal planes of Pt. However, a slight increase in peak height and area was observed after 11 applications, as compared to the pre-application stage. In light of the modest decrease in nitrobenzene conversion, as demonstrated in Fig. 9, it can be hypothesized that the catalyst did not undergo significant agglomerative deactivation during the selective hydrogenation of nitrobenzene in the set experiments. The improvement in p-Aminophenol selectivity in the nitrobenzene hydrorearrangement reaction, in response to Pt-based catalysts, is attributed to the suppression of hydrogenation activity by high-valent Pt. In accordance with this principle, Fig. 11(b) displays the X-ray photoelectron spectra of Pt/CS2 catalysts after 11 cycles, which reveals a substantial proportion of high-valent Pt is still present. This observation highlights the stability of the Pt-S-C structure under hydrogenation conditions, as it suggests that the strong interaction between Pt and S during the nesting process is able to maintain a substantial component of high-valent Pt ions. In addition, the stability of the Pt/CS2 catalyst was further explored using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The results, presented in Fig. 12 , are consistent with those obtained from the XRD characterization and reveal no significant change in particle size after 11 cycles of application. We also conducted ICP-OES/MS tests on the metal content of the catalyst before and after use. As shown in Table S2, there was no significant leaching of Pt before and after the reaction. These findings further affirm the excellent reusability of Pt/CS2 in the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to p-Aminophenol. 3.3 Discussion on hydrogenation mechanism The selective catalytic hydrogenation rearrangement of nitrobenzene is a complex four-step reaction, as depicted in Fig. 13. The process involves the adsorption of nitrobenzene on a Pt-based catalyst, which leads to the gradual formation of the intermediate product phenylhydroxylamine under a hydrogen atmosphere. However, phenylhydroxylamine is highly unstable and can undergo hydrogen replacement by breaking the NO bond, resulting in the formation of aniline. Additionally, a portion of phenylhydroxylamine may detach from the catalyst surface and undergo the Bamberger rearrangement reaction in acidic aqueous solution, resulting in the transfer of the phenolic hydroxyl group to the para position and the formation of the desired target product, p-Aminophenol. The superior catalytic performance of the Pt/CS2 catalyst in the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene to p-Aminophenol has been extensively investigated and analyzed through the use of various characterization techniques, such as X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), as well as through the evaluation of reaction results, as shown in Fig. 6 and Table 3. Our findings suggest that the increase in sulfur doping leads to the abundance of sulfur-containing sites on the carrier, which in turn facilitates a reduction in the particle size of Pt metal, stabilizing after reaching a certain sulfur content. This demonstrates the ability of sulfur to regulate metal size to a certain extent. Sulfur plays a crucial role in anchoring the metal and suppressing metal hydrogenation activity through its strong inter-electronic interaction with Pt, decreasing the electron cloud density on the Pt metal surface, increasing the number of higher valence Pt ions with lower hydrogenation activity, and ultimately resulting in the most suitable catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene through the synergistic effect of size and electron effects. Additionally, the anchoring position of S strengthens the interaction force between the metal and the carrier, thereby enhancing the adhesion of the metal to the carrier surface, which in turn leads to a higher stability of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, this study examines the preparation of p-Aminophenol through the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene by regulating the particle size and electronic state of Pt metal through sulfur doping of the carbon carrier. The results demonstrate that the defective sites on the activated carbon carrier increase with increasing sulfur doping, leading to a reduction in Pt metal particle size that stabilizes after reaching a certain sulfur content. Furthermore, sulfur doping results in a transfer of electrons from Pt to the sulfur-doped activated carbon carrier, reducing the electron cloud density on the Pt surface and increasing the proportion of high-valent Pt. By controlling the sulfur content within a reasonable range, the catalyst exhibits both good selectivity and acceptable activity. The catalyst also demonstrates good catalytic activity and selectivity after several cycles, with its physical properties remaining unchanged. These findings suggest that the use of metal catalysts on sulfur-doped carbon carriers may provide a more sustainable and efficient alternative to conventional metal-based catalysts for catalyzing chemical reactions (Fig. 13 ). coredata.dc:description: Nitrobenzene catalytic hydrogenation is the main synthesis method for the preparation of p-Aminophenol, but it is a great challenge to manufacture a catalyst with excellent catalytic performance. In this study, the authors explored the impact of S-doping on the catalytic performance of the platinum-based catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of nitrobenzene for p-Aminophenol production. To this end, the activated carbon carrier was modified through high-temperature calcination with an impregnation technique that incorporates organic sulfur. The study further evaluated the effects of the amount of sulfur doping on the particle size of the catalyst as well as its performance. It was theorized that the strong interaction between S and platinum (Pt) resulted in the capture of some of the Pt electrons by the sulfur-doped activated carbon carrier, reducing the reactivity of the catalyst and suppressing the over-hydrogenation side reaction. As a result, the catalyst demonstrated improved selectivity towards the formation of p-Aminophenol.
coredata.dc:title: Sulfur-doped activated carbon supported platinum species as robust catalysts for nitrobenzene hydrogenation to p-Aminophenol
